answers.answer: Well what you are describing does sound like psychosis but given that any number of conditions can cause that its best for him to have a g.p. do full physical tests and as well check for any potential side effects or interactions of his medications and then they can refer him to a psychiatrist if warranted who can make further decisions from there.
Could be cause by an underlying medical condition, but it is psychosis and may be psychosis from depression and not schizophrenia.He must go to the Doctor immediately.

Schizophrenia does not usually start in middle age.  People who have schizophrenia will typically experience the onset of it in their teens, 20's, or 30's.With your father's history of both diabetes and coronary artery disease, he might be experiencing some brain complications due to poor physical health.  Either diabetes or coronary artery disease can interfere with the flow of oxygen and glucose to the brain.  When the brain is functioning poorly at a physical level, then a person's thoughts, behavior, and emotions can become disturbed.He does need help, and the process should start with his primary care doctor.  He may or may not need a psychiatrist, after his physical condition has been thoroughly checked out.
